content: That’s not true. Having a simpler to understand product may reduce friction and make the learning curve shorter. But it doesn’t help with adoption. That depends more on the product positioning and how useful is it. In fact, having a common UI can be counterproductive, because there’s a risk a first time user forgets about the product if it’s not interesting — or intriguing — enough. Snapchat’s UI and the fact it’s not intuitive and requires some learning is key for the app success, some have said: ‘The reason people love (Snapchat) is because it requires some level of tribal knowledge’Ben Wilkinshttps://medium.com/figma-design/designers-weigh-in-did-snapchat-succeed-because-of-its-controversial-ui-17eab17647d8
